and unprofitable;--th other, rich ilowery

From the "Gaceta MercantiI, . Of Buenes Ayres,


Oct. oath, 1896


In the beginning of this month We pub
lished an important notice, derived from re
spectacle letters from England, which let
ters assured us that in Europe there existed
project of dividing Spanish America into
two vast empires; and we have now seen orig
NAL letters from France, dates to the mid
die of August, which, referring to private
intelligence from England, state, in a posi-
tive manner, that in Col onbia has originated
this very project of dividing between two
men the lives, the fortunes and the liberties

[7'ransiated for The IFilmingtea;aa ]


INTERESTING.

OF frultless argument, the other that OF re-


fined feeling or exquisite description. Com
pare one page of genuine poetry, or rich IL
structlve prose, with another Of harsh, stub


porn erascible debatery, and what man of
taste ana feeling would not repose, after en-
countering the thorny maze of the latter.
with enhanced enjoyment in the grateful
ease and elegance of the former. These re-
marks apply to style and dict,on alone. but
the difference in moral excellence and intel
lectual range and elevation is not less strik-
ing. Where is the beautiful and sublime of
Politics? In a Washington, perhaps, we
may find both; but how many Washingtons
has the world produced since its creation.
think not another so grandly virtuous, so
brave, so pure in principle, so immensely
tar removed from the communicating touch
OF the demon of Politics, Ambition. But in
Poetry, even Shakespeare is not unique.
1t would be trite and unnecessary to mention
the long cmblazoned list of names who have
won the need of immortality by genius a.
lone. While the politician and diplomatist
have been schooling their lips and features
to deception, and "laying the flattcring unc-
ton to their hearts" that all is for the pub
lie veal, and anticipating future aggran-
aizement from present chicanery, the Pact,
"the world forgetting, by the world forgot"
IN the solitude, perhaps, of a lonely cottage,
has been framing the witching melody at
whose charmed tones all hearts should vi
brate, from the lord Of palace to the wan
dering and harmless mendicant. H.

The Duke Of York.-It is with extreme regret
VIC have to announce that no further hopes are
entertained for the preservation of the Duke OF
York. 1t is stated on authority on which the
greatest reliance may be placed, that with view
of keeping his Royal Hghness free from bodily
pain, no farther medicines will be administered
to him to arrest the sure but slow progress of
his inveterate disease. In few days, at latest,
We say with heartfelt sorrow, the public will
learn the melancholy tidings of his departure to
that "bourne from whence no traveller re-
turns" The Sacrament was administered to
him by the bishop Of London on the 28th De-
cember

Rogers Of fLondon, who was burnt at smithfeld,
1555.--N Y. Post.
LONDON, Jan. z.

Mr.. Jared Sparks, Editor of the North Amer
lean Review, has made arrangements with Judge
Washington for publishing an entire edition of
General Washington's Works. to consist OF
his letters to the Governor cf Virginia during the
French war, his State Papers, Official Corrcspon-
dencc, both military and civil, and such of his
private letters as may be deemed suited for pub
licaton; the whole to be comprised in series of
volumes, with notes and illustrations by the cs-
tccmed editor.

All persons indebted to the Estate of JOHN
KEMP, late of Wilmington, Card-maker, dec,
are requested to make payment, and all persons
having CLAIMS ON said estate, are also desired to
exhibit them duly attested, when they will be
Immediately paid.

ridiculed the convention formed in Buenos


Ayres in 1928 with the Spanish Commits


sioners. 1t had progressed and been con-


Quoted with so much reserve, that it was on


ly recently developed, when put into ope-


ration by certain agents of the Holy Alli-


ance; such, for example, are Prince Ester
hazy, Count Paimeia, both ambassadors


resident in London, the former for Austria,


the second for Portugai-including Mr..


Hartado,~ who is supposed to be completely
initiated in the project, and is laboring with


activity in negotiating its adoption, even on


the part of England. 1t is said that the


French Government is likewise at the bot


tom of the business, maintaining, however,


the greatest circumspection. probably a.


waiting the fiat os Great Britain, without


whose cooperation it is in vain to hope for


the success of any European scheme for
planting itself ON the territory OF America.


We do not admire at the project, nor at all
which is said on the subject respecting the


Holy Alliance. Nor do we at the generos-
ity Of the European Powers. What we do
admire at, and what will appear most sin
gular before our readers, is, that the name
of Columbia should appear as taking a part


IN this business, and part so conspicuous.


1t is question worthy of examination, how
this intervention of Colombia is to be resolved:
out without entering deeply into the ques-
tion, an observation is started, at once,
which disburthens us of every doubt. 1t
seems TO be a fact that such plan has ex-
listed ard docs exist: another fact is that it
cannot be realized except by one of two
modes: either with the express consent of the
first maritime power in Europe, and of the
first OF that character in Ameriea;-.or with
tho accord and consent Of the States estab-
ilshcd in the formerly Spanish Colonies.
But there is existing, likewise, another fact.
which is that both England and the United
States are strongly compromised by the
most solemn acts, to resist any attempt by
Europe to ointroduce herself in America, with
powerful intervention there is existing,
still, another--that England. in such pro-
ject, must see directly attack kcd the base of
her former exterior policy, which consists
in diminishing, by every possible mean, the
sphere q influence of foreign Governments;
and that the Y. States, in such project, can
not but be aware ofthe great danger to which
their liberty is exposed, seeing thus blasted
the progress of the sacred cause throughout
America; and all these facts being evident,
it results that the said project can only be
founded or sustained upon calculation on
the consent of all, or, at least, of greater
part Of the new states.


1t is not necessary that we introduce here
a particular notice Of Brazil. 1t must be re.
ceived as established that its Government is
one of the two to which this new monster is
to give birth. Mexico decapitates Empe-
rors She has to dread the vengeance of
him who is to come in royal robes or per-
haps he who is designated would do well to
bear 10 mind the old proverb, El 9ae Aace
ua eesto Aara I'm ciento." [I.iterally, he
who makes one maund can make hun
dred.)


The argentine Republic is engaged in
actual struggle, and in struggle which will
be bloody, against these imperial ideas which
are appearing in every direction to iismem-
Der her, and if it be possible, to extingnish
i'll her every sentiment of liberty or civili-
cation.


Guatemala and Chile encounter difficult
ties in organizing themselves. They seek
to enjoy the greatest possible liberty; and
this is problem not SO easy to resolve as
that of making one man free, and enslaying
a whole people. What remains to us? Bo-
lvia. Peru, and Columbia: three states in
which one only chief sways his influence: and
which chief has established, or is about es-
tablishing, in two of them, a hereditary and
imperial form ofgovernment, and proposes
to extend that form to the third--to Colom-
bia itself


Thus, then, not counting on England and
the United States for effecting the object of
such plan; nor on the disposition in favor of
it on the part of the four states above nam
edit being evident that the project can
never be realized with the consent of said
States nor with a s,lneriority of influence

The following draft Of law relating to
habHnal GrRnkardS, has been presented.
by the Grand Jury Of the State Of Maryland,
to the General Assembly Of that State, now
sitting. When we reflect upon the appall-
ing misery and distress produced in society
by the too free use of ardent spirits, We can
not but express an anxious wish for an anti
dote to counteract the evil. How manv are
there within the knowledge of every ndi-
vidnal. who are pursuing course OF habitu-
al drunkenness, to the loss of reputation,
waste of property, and ruin of families.
Drunkenness is the mammoth vice Of this
country, and its baneful effects upon the
community are without parallel.


For the sake of moral Improvement on
the part of this class Of citizens of our own
state, (and it is by no means small one) We
hope that similar acts may, as soon as posi-
BILE, find place among the laws of this
state; for this is the only means by which
the evil can be met and its progress arrest
ed.

The pleasure ofhaying oar at6ts--What
pleasure it is to pay our debts It seems
to flow from combination Of circumstances,
each of which isproductive of a specific hap
pness. In the first place, it removes that
uneasness which a true spirit feels from de-
pendence and obligation, 1t affords pleas.
ure to the creditor, and, therefore. gratfcs
our social affection. 1t promises that future
confidence which is so interesting to an hon
est mind. It opens prospect of being readl-
iy supplied with what VIC want OH future
1t leaves consciousness of our
own virtue; and it is a measure which we
know to be right, both III point OF justice and
sound economy. Finally it is main sup
port of reputation.


The latest accounts from the Havana,

Aingudqr CireHnSt0nrc.--Thc truth Of The fol-
lowing extraordinary circumstance may be reii-
ed on, as there are several gentlemen in town
who can testify its yeracty. family Of Indi-
ans from the lake Of the Two Mountains, during
their hunting excursion last summer, caught a
young Bear about two weeks old; Squaw Of
the party determined to bring it up, for which
purpose she weaned her own child boy Of a
bout one year old and took the cub TO nurse in
its place. The cub in a short time became vc-
lry fond OF its adopted mother, and would search
her Out from amongst a crowd; when recognized,
he would search and tease her until she would
give HIM access to her breast, lfhe thought he
had been too long neglected ofreceiving food as
her adopted sucking, he would signify his wish
es laying hold other breast, and would growl and
show his dsplcas'lre if taken away before his ar-
petite had been thoroughly s.,ated.

On Sunday week, A. M. the thermometer
at Whitehall, New-York was thirty-eight degrees
below zero The coolest weather ever experi-
enced at that place. On the 18th ult. the ice in
the Niagara river had formed bridge complete
y across from the United States to his Maesty's
dominions.

Peter Martin, a free man of colour, was found
murdered in one of the streets ofPetcrsburg on
Wednesday morning last. The body was stab
bed i'll several places. Another colorcd man has
been arrested on suspicion of having done the
bloody decd.

We noticed last week. a statement in a
Philadelphia paper, that orders had been
received to launch and tit out the national
vessels OH that naval station. The New
York Gazette states that similar orders have
been received by the Commanaer of the Ma
Wy Yard at Brooklyn. These orders, it is
supposed, have grown out of the recent war
like news from Europe. We concur with
the editors in the excellence Of the maxim
in time OF peace prepare for war.'-i6.


A letter from Bagdad mentions the death
OF Persian Princess, the daughter of Abas
Mira, fifteen days after her marriage with
the Prince Of kermanshah. II is generally
believed some rivals of the Iiarem, Jealous
OF her beauty and engaging manners, de-
stroyed her by means of poison. The funcr-
al was attended by Nephew CT the King
OF Persia, and many Mobiles of high rank, in
consequence Of the great respect in which
she was held. The marriage OF this unfor
tunatc Lady was celebrated in style Of
grandeur and magniicence seldom witness
cd by tie Persians. From her fathers res
ldencc the procession passed through a
double line of troops, extending two leagues.
consisting Of about $4,000 men. Neither cx
pense nor exertions were spared to give ev
cry effect to the ceremony according to A.
static ideas of paseantry.

BE it enacted by the General Assembly of Ma
ryland, That from and after the passage of this
law, habltual drunkenness shall be, and hereby
is declared to be misdemeanor, and as such, the
subject of presentnent and indictment in the
several Courts of this state having criminal .ill-
risdiction.


And be it further enacted, That all persons
who shall hereafter be convicted in any of the
said Courts, of s'Habitual Drunkenness" shall
be considered and treated as Lunatics, and the
Court before whom said conviction shall take
place, shall have, and exercise all the powers
over the person and estates Of the said person so
convicted as are now legally exercised by the
chancellor in cases of Lunatics, by the visitation
of God


And be it further enacted, That in case said
convict shall not have sufficient means to main
tain him or her in the Hospital of the state, he
or she shall be committed to the Alms-IIouse of
the county, for such length oftime as the Court
may in their discretion, think proper under all
the circumstances of the case, aud the said con.
vct shall be treated, whilst in the hms-IIo,ise,
i'll such manner, and subjected to such restrsnts
ofhis or her liberty. and such exercises and en-
ployment, as the physician to tie institution may
prescribe for his or her restoration to health

Pose,ffy Of John Rogers.--The descendants of
this famous marty, whose memory is preserved
IN the New-Ensand primer, and the representa-
ton OF whose suferings, in 4 villainous wood
cut, children gaze at with brcathess awe, are
yet New-England. II would seem also that
the honor ofhaving this eminent rcformer for an
ancestor is not thought lightly Of, and that the
genealogy which attests u descent from his
lons, is preserved with as much eXactness and
reverence as that of the nobility of other coun-
tries. A New Hampshire paper mentions the
death Of Miss Anna Rogers, of Exeter in that
state, aged rs, and linealy descended from this
dvine.-She was the daughter of Rev. Daniel
Rogers of Exeter. who died in 1885, who was the
son of Rev. John Rogers, of Ipswich, who died

full articles.article:
Politics How dry how little it resem-
bies the variegated parterre of Poetry The
one a dry stubble field, at once unhandsome
and unprofitable;--th other, rich ilowery
vale, balmy with the dews of Spring, and
dispensing sweets on every breeze. The
one calculated to excite and foster, only an
overreaching circumventing spirit; the o.
ther elicitng and ornamenting the noblest
and purest emotions of our nature. One the
language Of cool, double-tongued diplomacy

full articles.headline:
[7'ransiated for The IFilmingtea;aa ]


INTERESTING.
full articles.article:
From the "Gaceta MercantiI, . Of Buenes Ayres,


Oct. oath, 1896


In the beginning of this month We pub
lished an important notice, derived from re
spectacle letters from England, which let
ters assured us that in Europe there existed
project of dividing Spanish America into
two vast empires; and we have now seen orig
NAL letters from France, dates to the mid
die of August, which, referring to private
intelligence from England, state, in a posi-
tive manner, that in Col onbia has originated
this very project of dividing between two
men the lives, the fortunes and the liberties

OF frultless argument, the other that OF re-


fined feeling or exquisite description. Com
pare one page of genuine poetry, or rich IL
structlve prose, with another Of harsh, stub


porn erascible debatery, and what man of
taste ana feeling would not repose, after en-
countering the thorny maze of the latter.
with enhanced enjoyment in the grateful
ease and elegance of the former. These re-
marks apply to style and dict,on alone. but
the difference in moral excellence and intel
lectual range and elevation is not less strik-
ing. Where is the beautiful and sublime of
Politics? In a Washington, perhaps, we
may find both; but how many Washingtons
has the world produced since its creation.
think not another so grandly virtuous, so
brave, so pure in principle, so immensely
tar removed from the communicating touch
OF the demon of Politics, Ambition. But in
Poetry, even Shakespeare is not unique.
1t would be trite and unnecessary to mention
the long cmblazoned list of names who have
won the need of immortality by genius a.
lone. While the politician and diplomatist
have been schooling their lips and features
to deception, and "laying the flattcring unc-
ton to their hearts" that all is for the pub
lie veal, and anticipating future aggran-
aizement from present chicanery, the Pact,
"the world forgetting, by the world forgot"
IN the solitude, perhaps, of a lonely cottage,
has been framing the witching melody at
whose charmed tones all hearts should vi
brate, from the lord Of palace to the wan
dering and harmless mendicant. H.

full articles.headline:
Rogers Of fLondon, who was burnt at smithfeld,
1555.--N Y. Post.

LONDON, Jan. z.
full articles.article:
The Duke Of York.-It is with extreme regret
VIC have to announce that no further hopes are
entertained for the preservation of the Duke OF
York. 1t is stated on authority on which the
greatest reliance may be placed, that with view
of keeping his Royal Hghness free from bodily
pain, no farther medicines will be administered
to him to arrest the sure but slow progress of
his inveterate disease. In few days, at latest,
We say with heartfelt sorrow, the public will
learn the melancholy tidings of his departure to
that "bourne from whence no traveller re-
turns" The Sacrament was administered to
him by the bishop Of London on the 28th De-
cember

Mr.. Jared Sparks, Editor of the North Amer
lean Review, has made arrangements with Judge
Washington for publishing an entire edition of
General Washington's Works. to consist OF
his letters to the Governor cf Virginia during the
French war, his State Papers, Official Corrcspon-
dencc, both military and civil, and such of his
private letters as may be deemed suited for pub
licaton; the whole to be comprised in series of
volumes, with notes and illustrations by the cs-
tccmed editor.

exhibit them duly attested, when they will be
Immediately paid.


VIM. MARSHALL.
I'd mo-, 5th, 1927. 21-4tp.

ridiculed the convention formed in Buenos


Ayres in 1928 with the Spanish Commits


sioners. 1t had progressed and been con-


Quoted with so much reserve, that it was on


ly recently developed, when put into ope-


ration by certain agents of the Holy Alli-


ance; such, for example, are Prince Ester
hazy, Count Paimeia, both ambassadors


resident in London, the former for Austria,


the second for Portugai-including Mr..


Hartado,~ who is supposed to be completely
initiated in the project, and is laboring with


activity in negotiating its adoption, even on


the part of England. 1t is said that the


French Government is likewise at the bot


tom of the business, maintaining, however,


the greatest circumspection. probably a.


waiting the fiat os Great Britain, without


whose cooperation it is in vain to hope for


the success of any European scheme for
planting itself ON the territory OF America.


We do not admire at the project, nor at all
which is said on the subject respecting the


Holy Alliance. Nor do we at the generos-
ity Of the European Powers. What we do
admire at, and what will appear most sin
gular before our readers, is, that the name
of Columbia should appear as taking a part


IN this business, and part so conspicuous.


1t is question worthy of examination, how
this intervention of Colombia is to be resolved:
out without entering deeply into the ques-
tion, an observation is started, at once,
which disburthens us of every doubt. 1t
seems TO be a fact that such plan has ex-
listed ard docs exist: another fact is that it
cannot be realized except by one of two
modes: either with the express consent of the
first maritime power in Europe, and of the
first OF that character in Ameriea;-.or with
tho accord and consent Of the States estab-
ilshcd in the formerly Spanish Colonies.
But there is existing, likewise, another fact.
which is that both England and the United
States are strongly compromised by the
most solemn acts, to resist any attempt by
Europe to ointroduce herself in America, with
powerful intervention there is existing,
still, another--that England. in such pro-
ject, must see directly attack kcd the base of
her former exterior policy, which consists
in diminishing, by every possible mean, the
sphere q influence of foreign Governments;
and that the Y. States, in such project, can
not but be aware ofthe great danger to which
their liberty is exposed, seeing thus blasted
the progress of the sacred cause throughout
America; and all these facts being evident,
it results that the said project can only be
founded or sustained upon calculation on
the consent of all, or, at least, of greater
part Of the new states.


1t is not necessary that we introduce here
a particular notice Of Brazil. 1t must be re.
ceived as established that its Government is
one of the two to which this new monster is
to give birth. Mexico decapitates Empe-
rors She has to dread the vengeance of
him who is to come in royal robes or per-
haps he who is designated would do well to
bear 10 mind the old proverb, El 9ae Aace
ua eesto Aara I'm ciento." [I.iterally, he
who makes one maund can make hun
dred.)


The argentine Republic is engaged in
actual struggle, and in struggle which will
be bloody, against these imperial ideas which
are appearing in every direction to iismem-
Der her, and if it be possible, to extingnish
i'll her every sentiment of liberty or civili-
cation.


Guatemala and Chile encounter difficult
ties in organizing themselves. They seek
to enjoy the greatest possible liberty; and
this is problem not SO easy to resolve as
that of making one man free, and enslaying
a whole people. What remains to us? Bo-
lvia. Peru, and Columbia: three states in
which one only chief sways his influence: and
which chief has established, or is about es-
tablishing, in two of them, a hereditary and
imperial form ofgovernment, and proposes
to extend that form to the third--to Colom-
bia itself


Thus, then, not counting on England and
the United States for effecting the object of
such plan; nor on the disposition in favor of
it on the part of the four states above nam
edit being evident that the project can
never be realized with the consent of said
States nor with a s,lneriority of influence

The following draft Of law relating to
habHnal GrRnkardS, has been presented.
by the Grand Jury Of the State Of Maryland,
to the General Assembly Of that State, now
sitting. When we reflect upon the appall-
ing misery and distress produced in society
by the too free use of ardent spirits, We can
not but express an anxious wish for an anti
dote to counteract the evil. How manv are
there within the knowledge of every ndi-
vidnal. who are pursuing course OF habitu-
al drunkenness, to the loss of reputation,
waste of property, and ruin of families.
Drunkenness is the mammoth vice Of this
country, and its baneful effects upon the
community are without parallel.


For the sake of moral Improvement on
the part of this class Of citizens of our own
state, (and it is by no means small one) We
hope that similar acts may, as soon as posi-
BILE, find place among the laws of this
state; for this is the only means by which
the evil can be met and its progress arrest
ed.

The pleasure ofhaying oar at6ts--What
pleasure it is to pay our debts It seems
to flow from combination Of circumstances,
each of which isproductive of a specific hap
pness. In the first place, it removes that
uneasness which a true spirit feels from de-
pendence and obligation, 1t affords pleas.
ure to the creditor, and, therefore. gratfcs
our social affection. 1t promises that future
confidence which is so interesting to an hon
est mind. It opens prospect of being readl-
iy supplied with what VIC want OH future
1t leaves consciousness of our
own virtue; and it is a measure which we
know to be right, both III point OF justice and
sound economy. Finally it is main sup
port of reputation.

full articles.headline: IRELAND.
full articles.article:
Extreme distress exists in the Southern dis
tricts of Ireland. 1t was declared at public
meeting i'll Cork, by the Rev. Mr. G'Gagan,
that such wretchedness and misery was never be-
fore witnessed; that besides those who exhibit
their poverty in the streets, there were others
still worse off who were housed in lanes and gar
rets, "without even a particle of straw or cover


ing, much less of food, and in this state they re-
NAMED until they expired of absolute famine

In reading the above sentence am a little
puzzled to find out the meaning; and when
venture conjecture as to the meaning in
tended to be conveyed, doubt the possibil-
ity of the facts stated. Does the writer of
the above, mean that the "other articles"
only, were supplied in abundance". Ifso,
there must have been sad deficiency of the
necessary essentiaAties of good and COM
Portable breakfast. But if he includes the
other two clauses ofthe sentence in the ref
erence of abundance" the sentence will ap
pear somewhat laughable. To furnish cuff
of coffee "in abundance" seems little i'm
probable. and the attempt would raise a
smile; but when we think of fezv marn.
cakes being "suhhHed in abundance" 1--WE are
forced to laugh outright. This seems like
Plentiful searci.y

full articles.article:
Late European advices have been receiv-
ed at NewYork. We have but barely time
TO give the following paragraph as news
from Spain, which comes, not direct, but BY
the way OF France:


The Courier Francais Of December Goth,
says:-


"Authcntc accounts frcm Madrid state tha,
King Ferdinand, in consequence of the ultmat
TN which has been presented to him, recurring
him to answer it without delay, and without sub.
tertugr, has recognised the Constitutions, GOV.
ernncnt and Charter Of Portugal, has promised
to scnd AN Ambassador to Lisbon, and to receive,
one from the Regency; TO break OIL all kinds ot
con!inatlons and completely with the Portuguese
rebellion, and TO give all other kinds of saisf..c-
ton which have been required Of him bv Eng
land"


ihis intelligence is confirmed hv all the o.
tAcr French papers. The Courier Francais ads:


III now renains to he seen what guarantee
will be required OF Ferdinand, and what further
pledge ne can offer of fidelity to the most SOL
elnn promises The first and most essential Of
these guarantees would be an irrcvocablt. ,,nun.
ciation ofabsolute power--of that power, with
out check and control Of which lie has not been
ahic 20 iaakc any other use than torcccac bnly
.o'i. s'olti!ie ~ i.iislollune, anu 10 Dig under
his feet an abyss into which he cannot fail to nrc
cipitate himself and his people, unless he can Be
deprived of a weapon. which is equally fatal 10
the throne and to all SPAIN


Meantime the priesthood and tanatical party
N Spain, behaved AS fiarously and nallly AS G.
rer-The Constitutional of December eth,
says.-

the converts situated near the frontiers Of Portu-

into magazines Of clothing and accoutrcmcnts
and into arsenals. 1t is added, that the clergy
lavished gold in the province of Galicia ard at
Salamanca. to obtain recruits and swell the ranks
CT the Portuguese insurgents. How treat with
the Government of such country"

Aingudqr CireHnSt0nrc.--Thc truth Of The fol-
lowing extraordinary circumstance may be reii-
ed on, as there are several gentlemen in town
who can testify its yeracty. family Of Indi-
ans from the lake Of the Two Mountains, during
their hunting excursion last summer, caught a
young Bear about two weeks old; Squaw Of
the party determined to bring it up, for which
purpose she weaned her own child boy Of a
bout one year old and took the cub TO nurse in
its place. The cub in a short time became vc-
lry fond OF its adopted mother, and would search
her Out from amongst a crowd; when recognized,
he would search and tease her until she would
give HIM access to her breast, lfhe thought he
had been too long neglected ofreceiving food as
her adopted sucking, he would signify his wish
es laying hold other breast, and would growl and
show his dsplcas'lre if taken away before his ar-
petite had been thoroughly s.,ated.


Montreal Herald

On Sunday week, A. M. the thermometer
at Whitehall, New-York was thirty-eight degrees
below zero The coolest weather ever experi-
enced at that place. On the 18th ult. the ice in
the Niagara river had formed bridge complete
y across from the United States to his Maesty's
dominions.

Peter Martin, a free man of colour, was found
murdered in one of the streets ofPetcrsburg on
Wednesday morning last. The body was stab
bed i'll several places. Another colorcd man has
been arrested on suspicion of having done the
bloody decd.

French Consul had arrived there from ST.
Domingo, who stated that revelation had
broke out in the s,and between the blacks
ard muattoes, ard that the latter had col

We noticed last week. a statement in a
Philadelphia paper, that orders had been
received to launch and tit out the national
vessels OH that naval station. The New
York Gazette states that similar orders have
been received by the Commanaer of the Ma
Wy Yard at Brooklyn. These orders, it is
supposed, have grown out of the recent war
like news from Europe. We concur with
the editors in the excellence Of the maxim
in time OF peace prepare for war.'-i6.


A letter from Bagdad mentions the death
OF Persian Princess, the daughter of Abas
Mira, fifteen days after her marriage with
the Prince Of kermanshah. II is generally
believed some rivals of the Iiarem, Jealous
OF her beauty and engaging manners, de-
stroyed her by means of poison. The funcr-
al was attended by Nephew CT the King
OF Persia, and many Mobiles of high rank, in
consequence Of the great respect in which
she was held. The marriage OF this unfor
tunatc Lady was celebrated in style Of
grandeur and magniicence seldom witness
cd by tie Persians. From her fathers res
ldencc the procession passed through a
double line of troops, extending two leagues.
consisting Of about $4,000 men. Neither cx
pense nor exertions were spared to give ev
cry effect to the ceremony according to A.
static ideas of paseantry.

the groom and bride were pointed out to
him. Somewhat surprised to see them at OPP
posite sides of the apartment, the minister
asked the man if he wished to be narried?-

but Of little benefit to "a mind diseased
all would not do and 'hc poor girl was evil

her quandum lover-gave them little
friendly advice, and then retired--the knot |

full articles.headline: IN .lC1relating to AaJitual dy4nhards
full articles.article:
BE it enacted by the General Assembly of Ma
ryland, That from and after the passage of this
law, habltual drunkenness shall be, and hereby
is declared to be misdemeanor, and as such, the
subject of presentnent and indictment in the
several Courts of this state having criminal .ill-
risdiction.


And be it further enacted, That all persons
who shall hereafter be convicted in any of the
said Courts, of s'Habitual Drunkenness" shall
be considered and treated as Lunatics, and the
Court before whom said conviction shall take
place, shall have, and exercise all the powers
over the person and estates Of the said person so
convicted as are now legally exercised by the
chancellor in cases of Lunatics, by the visitation
of God


And be it further enacted, That in case said
convict shall not have sufficient means to main
